item.description:
Again another Collective FYI, if you're interested in attending please RSVP so John knows who to look for!!! Sounds like it could be an interesting Sunday night!

 

A night of experimental fiction with  

Lance Olsen, Jane Unrue, and John Madera


Website: http://ada-books.com/

More Information: https://www.facebook.com/events/285300788191126/

Here's more information about the writers:

Lance Olsen (www.lanceolsen.com) is author of ten novels, one hypermedia text, four critical studies, four short-story collections, a poetry chapbook, and a textbook about fiction writing, as well as editor of two collections of essays about innovative contemporary fiction. His short stories, essays, poems, and reviews have appeared in hundreds of journals, magazines, and anthologies, including Conjunctions, Fiction International, Iowa Review, Village Voice, Time Out New York, BOMB, Hotel Amerika, and Best American Non-Required Reading.

Check out an interview with Olsen here: http://www.raintaxi.com/online/2010summer/olsen.shtml

Jane Unrue (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jane_Unrue) is an American writer of surreal and absurdist poetry and fiction. Unrue’s novella The House was published by Burning Deck in 2000; her collection Atlassed was published by Triple Press in 2005; the novella “Dear Mr. Erker” appeared in the final edition of 3rd bed. Life of a Star was published by Burning Deck in 2010. Unrue, born in Nevada, now lives in Boston and teaches at Harvard.

Check out a review of Unrue's LIFE OF A STAR here: http://brooklynrail.org/2010/07/books/fiction-our-lots-of-little

John Madera's fiction has appeared in Conjunctions, Opium Magazine, Featherproof Press, elimae, Jaded Ibis Press, Cow Heavy Books, and other venues. His criticism may be found in American Book Review, Bookforum, The Review of Contemporary Fiction, Rain Taxi: Review of Books, The Brooklyn Rail, Bookslut, The Collagist, DIAGRAM, The Millions, Powell’s Books’ “Review-a-Day,” The Quarterly Conversation, The Rumpus, Tarpaulin Sky, and Word Riot, and other venues. He is editing a collection of essays on the craft of writing (Publishing Genius Press). He edits the arts forum Big Other (www.bigother.com). Find more about him here: www.johnmadera.com
item.how_to_find_us: John is hosting this one! Please look at his picture!
item.name: Fiction Stranger than Fiction
